item.title: E.U. Countries Warn Britain on ‘Brexit’: You’ll Pay if You Leave Us
item.media:description: If Britons vote in the referendum on Thursday to leave the European Union, they can expect a tough and unforgiving response.
item.description: If they vote to depart the bloc, the British should expect an unforgiving response from Brussels, which is wary of other nations following suit.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Even Without Blast, 4 Hydrogen Bombs From ’66 Scar Spanish Village
item.media:description: José Manuel González Navarro at a contaminated area near Palomares, Spain. He remembers the day 50 years ago when an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, dropping four hydrogen bombs.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Decades after an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, Palomares remains haunted by high radiation levels, a hurried cleanup, health fears and stigma.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A British Divorce From Europe? Henry VIII Blazed the Trail
item.media:description: A poster to remain in the European Union in London features a picture of Winston Churchill.
item.description: The country’s vote on leaving the European Union recalls in some ways England’s break five centuries ago with the papacy, another great power across the Channel.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Anti-Immigration Poster Denounced by a Top ‘Brexit’ Advocate
item.media:description: A poster circulated by Nigel Farage’s U.K. Independence Party was condemned Sunday, days after lawmaker Jo Cox was killed.
item.description: Michael Gove, Britain’s justice secretary, said a campaign effort by Nigel Farage’s U.K. Independence Party “was the wrong thing to do.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Record 65 Million Displaced by Global Conflicts, U.N. Says
item.media:description: United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, center, during a visit at the refugee camp Kara Tepe on the Greek island of Lesbos, on Saturday.
item.description: The 2015 total included those fleeing marauders in South Sudan, drug gangs in Central America and the Islamic State in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Venezuelans Ransack Stores as Hunger Grips the Nation
item.description: A nation anxiously searches for ways to feed itself, as the economic collapse of recent years has left it unable to produce or import sufficient food.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: 11 Syrian Refugees Reported Killed by Turkish Border Guards
item.description: Most, including at least three children, were from the same extended family and were shot near the crossing at the town of Jisr al-Shoughour, Syrian activists and a monitoring group said.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Israel Approves Additional Funding for Settlements in West Bank
item.media:description: Israeli troops demolishing unlicensed sheds belonging to Palestinians near Yatta in the West Bank on Sunday.
item.description: The approximately $20 million in financing underlined Israel’s strengthened right-wing orientation and raised the ire of political opponents and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India, Needing Jobs, Eases Rules on Foreign Investment
item.media:description: A training room at a Flipkart, an e-commerce company in India, in August.
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.description: The changes are the most significant loosening of market restrictions since India began economic liberalization, with foreigners now permitted to own 100 percent of many companies.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Indonesia Confirms Seizing Fishing Boat in South China Sea, Defying Beijing
item.description: The boat and its crew were taken Friday after warships fired warning shots at Chinese vessels suspected of illegal fishing, an Indonesian official said.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Hong Kong Bookseller Finds Associates Challenging His Account of Detention
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee in Hong Kong, on Sunday, three days after saying that he was abducted by mainland police in October, held in solitary confinement and denied legal representation. Former colleagues and a woman claiming to be his girlfriend have disavowed his claims.
item.description: Lam Wing-kee publicly described months in mainland Chinese custody, but former colleagues and a woman who says she is his girlfriend have disputed what he said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: The Interpreter: ‘Brexit’ Debate Has Voters Asking: What Does it Mean to be English?
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on whether to remain in the European Union, Robert Tombs, a historian, discusses a growing sense of English identity.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: 5 Are Held in Russia After 14 Children Die in a Boating Accident
item.media:description: Emergency workers set out on Sunday to search for children missing after their canoes capsized Saturday in a sudden storm on Lake Syamozero in the Karelia region of Russia.
item.description: Camp instructors took the children out on a lake despite forecasts of storms, and investigators said some survivors spent hours in frigid water before being rescued.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Silence and Sobs as Parliament Honors Jo Cox, Slain British Lawmaker
item.media:description: Jo Cox, the member of Parliament who was killed on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Thomas Mair, the man charged with her murder, made a brief appearance in court via video link, as lawmakers paid tribute to their slain colleague.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Take a Number: The Rising Murder Count of Environmental Activists
item.media:description: A picture of Berta Cáceres placed at an altar during a demonstration outside Honduras’ embassy in Mexico City on June 15.
item.description: A new report by Global Witness puts last year’s death toll at 185, a sharp increase, with Brazil leading the way.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Trilobites: Saiga Population Grows After Mysterious Epidemic
item.media:description: A saiga mother and calf.
item.description: A recent census suggests the endangered antelopes in Kazakhstan are making modest gains after illness wiped out most of the species.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Virginia Raggi of Five Star Movement Sweeps Election for Rome’s Mayor
item.media:description: Supporters of the Five Star Movement celebrated in Rome on Monday.
item.description: An anti-establishment candidate also won in Turin, in major blows to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his governing Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Protests Return to Wukan, Chinese Village That Once Expelled Its Officials
item.media:description: Lin Zuluan, the Communist Party secretary of the village of Wukan.
item.description: The protests called for the release of a detained local leader and the resolution of a long-simmering dispute over land sales, residents said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: The Interpreter: What Is ‘Brexit’? A Look at the Debate and Its Wider Meaning
item.media:description: Britain will decide on Thursday whether to leave the European Union, and voters are deeply split.
item.description: As British voters weigh whether to leave the European Union, they are wading into questions about national identity and Britain’s place in the world.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Bombing in Kabul Kills Security Contractors, Officials Say
item.description: At least 14 Nepalese and Indian guards were killed while riding in a minibus to work at the Canadian Embassy, police officials said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: 6 Killed in Mexico During Teachers' Protest Against Education Reforms
item.description: Six people were killed and 53 injured in Mexico on Sunday when clashes broke out between members of a teachers' trade union and police at a protest in the state of Oaxaca.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Europe’s Emergency Workers Turn to Drones to Save Lives
item.description: A six-month training program for teams from Britain, Denmark, Iceland and Ireland aims to test the use of unmanned aircraft in emergencies.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Memo From Spain: Venezuela Casts a Long Shadow on Elections in Spain
item.media:description: Albert Rivera, the leader of Spain’s center-right Ciudadanos party, arriving in Venezuela in May at the invitation of opponents of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.description: Leaders of the leftist Podemos party once advised the government of Hugo Chávez in Venezuela, a country whose economic collapse is an issue in national elections next Sunday.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Decades Later, Sickness Among Airmen After a Hydrogen Bomb Accident
item.media:description: John H. Garman was in the United States Air Force when, in 1966, a fully loaded B-52 bomber on a Cold War nuclear patrol collided with a refueling jet high over the Spanish coast, freeing four hydrogen bombs that went tumbling toward a coastal farming village called Palomares. Mr. Garman was among those who were first on the scene of the crash.
item.media:credit: Raymond McCrea Jones for The New York Times
item.description: The Air Force says that there was no harmful radiation at the crash site in Spain, but interviews with dozens of men and details from declassified documents disagree.
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: At Okinawa Protest, Thousands Call for Removal of U.S. Bases
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Naha, the capital of the Japanese prefecture of Okinawa, protesting the United States military presence on the island. Organizers said that 65,000 people attended.
item.description: Organizers said the protest, billed as a memorial for a woman who was killed, was the largest demonstration against the United States’ presence in two decades.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: How Many Die in a Typical Terror Attack? Fewer Than You Think
item.description: Even so, what used to be symbolic acts have turned increasingly deadly, according to the Global Terrorism Database at the University of Maryland, which includes 140,000 attacks.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Magnet for Titanic Fans in an Unexpected Graveyard
item.media:description: The Fairview Lawn Cemetery in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on April 15, 2012, the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic.
item.description: Fairview Lawn Cemetery holds more victims of the world’s best-known shipwreck than any other place — including the grave of a certain J. Dawson.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Rise at 11? China’s Single Time Zone Means Keeping Odd Hours
item.description: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. in Urumqi, where clocks are set to Beijing time despite being 2,000 miles to the west.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Iran Says It Foiled One of the ‘Biggest Terrorism Plots Ever’
item.description: Several people were arrested over bombing attacks planned for June 16, and explosives were seized, the Intelligence Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Virginia Raggi of Five Star Movement Wins Rome Mayoral Race
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi of the Five Star Movement at a news conference in Rome on Monday.
item.description: Virginia Raggi, an anti-establishment newcomer who will be the city’s first female mayor, easily claimed a runoff victory amid anger about corruption and deteriorating city services.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Jo Cox and Britain’s Place in Europe
item.description: The “out” campaign countenanced the hatred that produced a political murder. Cox's legacy should be an open Britain in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Local Costs of the E.U. Refugee Deal
item.media:description: Migrants and refugees are stranded at the Greek port of Chios.
item.description: Greek villagers welcomed the migrants — until Athens got involved.
item.dc:creator: DAVID LEPESKA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Obama Needs to Protect the Iran Deal
item.description: Europe‘s banks still fear U.S. punishment if they enter Iran. Iranians ask if they’ve been betrayed. The president must rule out prosecution. Now.
item.dc:creator: SEYED HOSSEIN MOUSAVIAN and REZA NASRI

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
